awd_titl_txt: BD Spokes: SPOKE: MIDWEST: Collaborative: Advanced Computational Neuroscience Network (ACNN)
awd_abstract_narration:
Novel neuroscience tools and techniques are necessary to enable insight into the building blocks of neural circuits, the interactions between these circuits that underpin the functions of the human brain, and modulation of these circuits that affect our behavior. To leverage rapid technological development in sensing, imaging, and data analysis new ground breaking advances in neuroscience are necessary to facilitate knowledge discovery using data science methods. To address this societal grand challenge, the project will foster new interdisciplinary collaborations across computing, biological, mathematical, and behavioral science disciplines together with partnerships in academia, industry, and government at multiple levels. The Big Data Neuroscience Spoke titled Midwest: Advanced Computational Neuroscience Network (ACNN) is strongly aligned with the national priority area of neuroscience and brings together a diverse set of committed regional partners to enable the Midwest region to realize the promise of Big Data for neuroscience. The ACNN Spoke will build broad consensus on the core requirements, infrastructure, and components needed to develop a new generation of sustainable interdisciplinary Neuroscience Big Data research. ACNN will leverage the strengths and resources in the Midwest region to increase innovation and collaboration for the understanding of the structure, physiology, and function of the human brain through partnerships and services in education, tools, and best practices. 

The ACNN will design, pilot and support powerful neuroscientific computational resources for high-throughput, collaborative, and service-oriented data aggregation, processing and open-reproducible science. The ACNN Spoke framework will address three specific problems related to neuroscience Big Data: (1) data capture, organization, and management involving multiple centers and research groups, (2) quality assurance, preprocessing and analysis that incorporates contextual metadata, and (3) data communication to software and hardware computational resources that can scale with the volume, velocity, and variety of neuroscience datasets. The ACNN will build a sustainable ecosystem of neuroscience community partners in both academia and industry using existing technologies for collaboration and virtual meeting together with face-to-face group meetings. The planned activities of the ACNN Spoke will also allow the Midwest Big Data Hub to disseminate additional Big Data technologies resources to the neuroscience community, including access to supercomputing facilities, best practices, and platforms.

This award received co-funding from CISE Divisions of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure (ACI) and Information and Intelligent Systems (IIS).

por.por_cntn:
The advanced computational neuroscience network (ACNN; neurosciencenetwork.org) has been seed funded via the NSF Big Data program. ACNN was created to promote research and education in big data neuroscience. Through yearly workshops, the ACNN team has promoted big data neuroscience at institutions throughout the midwest and now in the South. The goal of this award was to start activities, such as workshop organization, team expansion and coordination to expand ACNN to the southern states. The team achieved four major goals as a result of this award.

 

  1. ACNN Expansion to Southern States. ACNN had a regional focus within the midwest region. ACNN has now expanded its network of collaborators, leading to the establishment of a Southern Pole Spoke. The Southern Pole Spoke now includes Georgia State University (partner: Jessica Turner), the University of Arkansas (partner: Josiah Leong), the University of Texas at Austin (partners: Susanne Ressl and Franco Pestilli), and the University of Alabama (partner: Sharlene Newman). A major outcome of this expansion was the Big Data Neuroscience workshop in September 2023, which took place at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa, AL. 

 

  1. Connect major neuroscience hubs with early research and education universities. As part of the newly created Southern ACNN Pole, we report new research and education collaborations between two of the large neuroscience research hubs  (University of Texas at Austin, Georgia Tech, and Georgia State) with two universities that are in the initial growing phases of neuroscience research and education (University of Arkansas and University of Alabama). To foster growth of neuroscience communities at the University of Alabama, we assisted with the organization of, and provided instruction at the University of Alabama workshop for neuroimaging data-analysis. Workshop attendees were a diverse group of researchers, with representation from R1, R2 universities as well as minor colleges. Future plans are underway for Josiah Leong to organize an ACNN Big Data workshop at the University of Arkansas in 2024, which plans to attract many attendees from other minor research institutions. 

 

  1. Bridge cognitive and computational neuroscience with structural and molecular neuroscience. An exciting aspect of the 2022 ACNN conference was the wide range in neuroscience research. The interdisciplinary aspect of this conference served as a first step to bridge the knowledge gap between cognitive and computational neuroscience with structural and molecular neuroscience. As a result of the 2022 workshop, joint grant proposals between computational and structural experts have been submitted.

 

  1. ACNN Workshops. The ACNN 2022 workshop was held at the University of Texas at Austin in September 2022. The meeting continued our work on the development of common practices and standardization to make it easier for neuroscience researchers to annotate and process data; to share data, tools and protocols, and to work with distributed high-performance computing environments. The workshop brought together over 100 members of the regional (midwest and southern), national, and the global neuroscience research community to promote data reuse, aggregation, result validation and new discoveries in neuroscience. The 2023 ACNN workshop was held at the University of Alabama in September 2023. The hands-on workshop focused on MRI data analysis using brainlife.io. 

 

ACNN has a strong presence in the midwest with a growing presence in the southern United States. Through expansion and collaboration with minor research institutions, as well as connections between computational, cognitive and structural, molecular neuroscience, ACNN continues to grow and strengthen the neuroscience research community.

Modified by: Franco Pestilli
